newsitem.title: USA: US WEST COAST CRUDES RISE, SUPPLIES BALANCED.
newsitem.headline: US WEST COAST CRUDES RISE, SUPPLIES BALANCED.

text.p: U.S. West Coast light crude prices tracked modest gains in oil futures Monday, while most trade for September deliveries of Alaskan crude oil appeared finished, traders said.

"I get the impression everyone is done," one trader said, adding that several refiners obtained supplies of Alaska North Slope (ANS) crude last week through formula deals, which are based on a monthly average of prices rather than a discount to West Texas Intermediate (WTI).
BP Oil, a main ANS seller, said last week it would stay out of the market while traders attended corporate meetings in Ohio.
Demand also fell after two refiners bought spot barrels of ANS last week, leaving the market $1.97 a barrel under September WTI, traders said.
The discount, which has shrunk since a mid-June cargo sold at minus $2.08, is expected to hold steady for the rest of September.
Traders said a combination of healthy refinery margins and milder foreign competition will keep the discount from swinging in favor of buyers or sellers.
Kern River and Wilmington grades fell with lower postings on Friday.
